title: Will China officially declare an air-defense identification zone (ADIZ) over any part of the South China Sea before 1 August 2017?
preds:
Start with very little understanding - thus 50% yes/no The role of ADIZs is to provide a means of anticipatory self-defense from incoming and immediate threats emanating above the high seas - No nation seriously threatens China. 5% No. ADIZs can only be legally applied in relation to preventing the unauthorized entry of aircraft into the national airspace. The SCS is not considered internationally as 
Chinese national airspace. %5 No. The establishment of an ADIZ must follow standard notice and coordination procedures. The Chicago Convention mandates timely and structured cooperation prior to establishing security zones in order to mitigate risks to civil aviation such as hazardous aircraft interceptions. Currently, China has not offered notice or attempted to coordinate. %5 No. 
Counter - China did not offer notice or coordinate when declaring the ECS ADIZ. %2.5 Yes. A South China Sea ADIZ would only increase the risk of confusion and miscommunication between China and commerical Airliners, thereby inhibiting one of the world’s great transit lanes. %5 No. SCS ADIZ would generate more situations for Chinese military incidents. %5 No. *Intuitive modification - basically my way of getting out explaining all my thoughts. I can find little reason why an ADIZ offers any benefit to China. Considering they cannot enforce the ECS ADIZ in regards to US, South Korean, Japanese, and Taiwanese military flights - why lose face further by opening a new ADIZ that they cannot enforce.
I think there needs to be advances in China's ability to enforce the ADIZ and actual threat to China. 28% No.

The Pentagon’s “2017 China Military Power Report” is worth the read to help understand China’s military strategy: https://www.defense.gov/Portals/1/Documents/pubs/2017_China_Military_Power_Report.PDF?ver=2017-06-06-141328-770 The report explains the current methods that China is using to assert sovereignty over disputed areas: 
“China continues to exercise low-intensity coercion to advance its claims in the East and South China Sea. During periods of tension, official statements and state media seek to portray china as reactive. They use an opportunistically time progression of incremental but intensifying steps to attempt to increase effective control over disputed areas and avoid escalation to military conflicts. China uses economic incentive and punitive trade policies to deter opposition to China’s actions in the region.”  Air Operations (page 51): “PLA’s planned development of a 5th generation fighter force will bolster its air-to-air capability. This will include J-20 and FC-31 fighter aircraft with key features including modern avionics and sensors that offer more timely awareness for operations in network-centric combat environments: radars with advance tracking and targeting capabilities.” 
However, these aircraft are not expected to enter service until 2018, at the earliest. 
“The airfields, berthing areas and resupply facilities at Spratly outposts will allow China to maintain a more flexible and persistent coast guard and military presence in the area. This would improve China’s ability to detect and challenge activities by rival claimants or third parties, widen the range of capabilities available to China, and reduce the time required to deploy them.”  “Chinese press discussed a “new normal” of persistent air patrols over the South China Sea by bomber and reconnaissance aircraft and also reemphasised China’s intent to conduct patrols in support of its East China Sea ADIZ”. There was no mention of an ADIZ over the South China Sea so its possible that China would rather intercept foreign flights on their own terms, rather than officially declare an ADIZ if they cannot knowingly enforce it at this time.  The report suggests, like previous comments from myself and other forecasters, that China is using alternative methods to an ADIZ to assert its sovereignty, such as the CCG and fishing ships. 
“Enlargement and modernisation of China’s Coast Guard (CCG) has improved china’s ability to enforce its maritime claims. It appears China is building a state-owned fishing fleet for its maritime militia force in the South China Sea” 
Also mentioned was the legality of China’s sovereign claims:
“The tribunal ruled that China’s “nine-dash line” cannot represent a lawful maritime claim to the extent that any of the claims it reflects would exceed the limits of China’s maritime entitlements under the convention”. Therefore the legality of an ADIZ over the South China Sea is questionable.

The prediction came in a 97-page annual report to Congress that saw advances throughout the Chinese military in 2016, funded by robust defense spending that the Pentagon estimated exceeded $180 billion. That is higher than China's official defense budget figure of 954.35 billion yuan ($140.4 billion). Chinese leaders, the U.S. report said, appeared committed to defense spending hikes for the "foreseeable future," even as economic growth slows. The report repeatedly cited China's construction of its first overseas naval base in Djibouti, which is already home to a key U.S. military base and is strategically located at the southern entrance to the Red Sea on the route to the Suez Canal. "China most likely will seek to establish additional military bases in countries with which it has a longstanding friendly relationship and similar strategic interests, such as Pakistan," the report said. Djibouti's position on the northwestern edge of the Indian Ocean has fueled worries in India that it would become another of China's 'string of pearls' of military alliances and assets ringing India, including Bangladesh, Myanmar and Sri Lanka. The report did not address India's potential reaction to a Chinese base in Pakistan. But Pakistan, the U.S. report noted, was already the primary market in the Asian-Pacific region for Chinese arms exports. That region accounted for $9 billion of the more than $20 billion in Chinese arms exports from 2011 to 2015 (para. 1-8). Stewart, P. (2017). Chinese President would not want to rock the boat right before the Communist Party meeting (after Aug 1, 2017). Therefore, there is no chance China will make any further provocation toward US. Usually China would provoke US if (1) it perceived US action as threatening; or (2) as a show of force for internal consumption. Case (1) is neutralized with the President visit earlier this year, and Trump only plan Asia visit in the Fall. Case (2) is chancy: the US may react a certain way that shames the current Chinese leadership. A gamble in economic good news may have better payoff, in game theory sense.

There is almost no chance with a nationalist president at the helm of the US that China would do anything to either antagonize the U.S. political spectrum or risk another international rebuke as they had with the International Court of Arbitration.
China maintains a long world view and likely does not see any reason to declare an ADIZ when their actions in the South China Sea have no resulted in any meaningful consequence.

As with its failed attempt at the East China Sea ADIZ, if China were to try to impose another failed ADIZ in the South China Sea, its neighbors, with certainty Japan, would immediately defy it with both military and commercial aircraft.  This would cause China to enter these negotiations from a position of weakness. Xi's history is to avoid self-inflicted humiliation, so I can't see him doing something so foolish, having learned from his predecessor.

China, Vietnam agree to keep South China Sea tensions in check Blanchard (2017) Mon May 15, states that: China and Vietnam will manage and properly control their maritime disputes, avoiding actions to complicate or widen them, so as to maintain peace in the South China Sea, the two nations said in a joint communique China released on Monday. Vietnam is the Southeast Asian country most openly at odds with China over the waterway since the Philippines pulled back from confrontation under President Rodrigo Duterte. After what China said were "positive" talks on the South China Sea last week between President Xi Jinping and Vietnamese President Tran Dai Quang, the joint statement stressed the need to control differences. Both countries agreed to "manage and properly control maritime disputes, not take any actions to complicate the situation or expand the dispute, and maintain peace and stability in the South China Sea", it added. The document, released by the Chinese Foreign Ministry, said both had a "candid and deep" exchange of views on maritime issues, and agreed to use an existing border talks mechanism to look for a lasting resolution. China claims 90 percent of the potentially energy-rich South China Sea. Besides Vietnam, Brunei, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Taiwan lay claim to parts of the route, through which about $5 trillion of trade passes each year. Last year, tension between Beijing and Hanoi rose after Taiwan and U.S. officials said China had placed surface-to-air missiles on Woody Island, part of the Paracels archipelago it controls (para. 1-7). General Secretary
Party General Secretary Xi Jinping
There is very little doubt that Xi Jinping, who will be 64 at the time of the congress, will continue for another term as General Secretary, the party's top leadership position and de facto leader in the one-party state. There is uncertainty, however, around whether the other personnel changes at the congress will signal that Xi would stay on for more than two terms per convention. Power projection (or force projection) is a term used in military and political science to refer to the capacity of a state "to apply all or some of its elements of national power - political, economic, informational, or military - to rapidly and effectively deploy and sustain forces in and from multiple dispersed locations to respond to crises, to contribute to deterrence, and to enhance regional stability."
This ability is a crucial element of a state's power in international relations. Any state able to direct its military forces outside the limited bounds of its territory might be said to have some level of power projection capability, but the term itself is used most frequently in reference to militaries with a worldwide reach (or at least significantly broader than a state's immediate area). Even states with sizable hard power assets (such as a large standing army) may only be able to exert limited regional influence so long as they lack the means of effectively projecting their power on a global scale. Generally, only a select few states are able to overcome the logistical difficulties inherent in the deployment and direction of a modern, mechanized military force.
While traditional measures of power projection typically focus on hard power assets (tanks, soldiers, aircraft, naval vessels, etc.), the developing theory of soft power notes that power projection does not necessarily have to involve the active use of military forces in combat. Assets for power projection can often serve dual uses, as the deployment of various countries' militaries during the humanitarian response to the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake illustrates. The ability of a state to project its forces into an area may serve as an effective diplomatic lever, influencing the decision-making process and acting as a potential deterrent on other states' behavior.

I have been looking into the legality of China declaring an ADIZ over the South China Sea and conditions under which an ADIZ can be implemented:  Just to clarify: Territorial sea is 12 miles wide, with a 24 mile contiguous zone, the 200 mile EEZ and the high seas. Article 1 of the 1958 Convention of the High Seas states: ‘The term “high seas” means all parts of the sea that are not included in the territorial sea or internal waters of a state”. (www.gc.noaa.gov/documents/8_1_1958_high_seas.pdf)  The conditions under which China could implement an ADIZ in the South China Sea:  “ADIZs are applied mostly during peacetime, “prohibited areas” or “restricted areas” of a States land areas or territorial waters over which the flight of the aircraft is restricted or prohibited and “danger areas” within or over which activities there may exist constituting a potential danger to aircraft flying over it”. It is possible that China could apply this condition to implement an ADIZ, if they have weaponised the disputed islands with missiles, therefore compromising the safety of aircraft flying over - however this is not recognised as Chinese territory so I doubt this argument would hold. 
Article 9 of the Chicago convention, recognises a parties right “in exceptional circumstances or during a period of emergency, or in the interest of public safety, and with immediate effects, temporarily to restrict or prohibit flying over the whole or any part of its territory”, but not over high seas. Airspace beyond sovereign territory is free for international air navigation.
“The right of a state to establish an ADIZ derives from its inherent right to self-defence. However, the UN charter only allows States to invoke this right in response to an armed attack.” This relates back to the initial purpose of ADIZs which came about in the Cold-war era to warn off nuclear strikes by long-range bombers. 
(Source: ‘The East China Sea Air Defense Identification Zone and International Law, Chinese Journal of International Law (Volume 14, Issue 2), June 2015’ https://academic.oup.com/chinesejil/article-abstract/14/2/271/391978/The-East-China-Sea-Air-Defense-Identification-Zone). Would just like to mention, I found some of the writing in this article biased, as it is written from Chinese perspective, but I have checked the facts against the UNCLOS.  In terms of the applicability of an ADIZ in the South China Sea beyond China’s EEZ: “The Chicago Convention recognises all states complete and exclusive sovereignty over airspace above their territory, defined as “the land areas and territorial waters adjacent thereto under the sovereignty, suzerainty, protection or mandate of such State”. It is implicit that areas beyond, such complete and exclusive sovereignty cannot be validly claimed ipso facto.” (Chinese Journal of International Law). This can be seen in Article 89 of the UNCLOS: “No state may validly purport to subject any part of the high seas to its sovereignty”. As an ADIZ is about protecting ones Sovereignty, China cannot claim the South China Sea as their territory, therefore an ADIZ would be invalid. If China were to declare an ADIZ off the South Coast they cannot legally shoot down any civilian aircraft under the Chicago Convention (1984), recognising “every state must refrain from resorting to the use of weapons against civil aircraft in flight and that in case of interceptions the lives of the persons on board and the safety of the aircraft must not be endangered”. “In case of non-compliance, fighters may be scrambled to verify the intentions of unidentified aircraft by standard ICAO visual signs established in Annex 2 of the Chicago convention. In critical situations the interceptor may initiate a divert manoeuvre such as flying across the intercepted aircrafts flight path, rocking its wings, or flashing external lights/select afterburners, or rolling out in the direction the intercepted aircraft is expected to turn. These measures do not amount to threat or use of force as prohibited by Article 2(4) of the Charter, nor do they involve the use of weapons.” (Chinese Journal of International Law)  However, in relation to what China can do to foreign military aircraft; the Chicago Convention is not applicable to State aircraft, which includes military. This means that for both sides the regulations aren't really there so it is up to the States involved to interpret the laws as they wish.
The US does not recognise ADIZs of foreign nations when: “foreign aircraft is not intending to enter national airspace, nor does the US apply its ADIZ procedures to foreign aircraft not intending to enter US airspace” - US Navy Commanders Handbook on the Law of Naval Operations. (http://www.jag.navy.mil/documents/NWP_1-14M_Commanders_Handbook.pdf)  While China could try to implement an ADIZ over the South China Sea off of the South coast of China, it is not legal for them to do so over the disputed islands in the South China Sea, such as the Parcel Islands, Macclesfield Bank, Scarborough Shoal and the Spratly Islands. Article 60.4 of the UNCLOS states: “The Coastal state may, where necessary establish reasonable safety zones around such artificial islands, installations and structures in which it may take appropriate measures to ensure the safety both of navigation and of artificial islands, installations and structures”. This is only valid within a States EEZ. Since none of the aforementioned disputed islands are within China’s EEZ, they cannot implement a safety zone.  UNCLOS: http://www.un.org/depts/los/convention_agreements/texts/unclos/unclos_e.pdf
Convention of the High Seas: www.gc.noaa.gov/documents/8_1_1958_high_seas.pdf

I doubt that China is willing to shoot down commercial Japanese airliners. When China declared its East China Sea ADIZ, Japan promptly ordered its commercial airline companies to ignore any Chinese ADIZ. It would be a violation of international law to shoot down a commercial airliner.  Even if Japan's commercial air companies were to defy Japanese law and comply with the ADIZ, China still would have to shoot down military aircraft of Japan, the U.S. and possibly other nations. When China declared its East China Sea ADIZ, it was swarmed within hours by U.S. and Japanese military aircraft. Please keep in mind that it is highly unusual for any nation to declare an ADIZ. This is not the same as an air traffic control region. Given the humiliation that China suffered over its one and only attempt at an ADIZ, I doubt that Xi is willing to suffer that same humiliation that his predecessor suffered. Now if China were to begin shooting down violators of the East China Sea ADIZ, then it would become likely that China would declare a South China Sea ADIZ. But I doubt that China is planning to get into a shooting war with the U.S., Japan and their allies any time soon, and doubt that Xi wants to be humiliated on the international stage.

I think it is unlikely that China will declare an ADIZ over the entire South China Sea, but I give increased odds on them extending the current ADIZ.  China has just about the capability to enforce a South China Sea ADIZ:
1) “The entire region is primarily under the jurisdiction of the PLANs (Peoples Liberation Army- Navy)”, which would avoid the error with the East China Sea ADIZ where it was under the coordination of the PLAAF and the PLANAF (Peoples Liberation Army Naval Air Force). 
2) The “PLANs South Sea Fleet (SSF) is made up of 3 naval aviation regiments. Each aviation regiment comprises of two combat regiments of 24 aircraft per regiment” based at Hainan Island (north end of South China sea).
3) J11 aircraft are capable of patrol and enforcement 
4) “PLANAF has deployed their J11’s stationed at Hainan Island to the Parcel Islands - a disputed territory.” 
5) Cuarteron Reef, Spratly Islands (also disputed) was under construction with what appeared to be radar stations, though the Chinese Foreign Ministry stated it was just a lighthouse - became operational in October 2016. (http://thediplomat.com/2016/03/cuarteron-reefs-new-radar-the-china-coast-guards-best-new-toy/)
6) PLANAF Airborne Early Warning aircraft based in Hainan which operate on a rotational basis - backs up radar data. 
7) China signalled in December 2016 that they had placed weapons on the Spratly Islands. (https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/15/world/asia/china-spratly-islands.html) (Rest of the info came from https://news.usni.org/2016/07/18/analysis-can-china-enforce-south-china-sea-air-defense-identification-zone)  If China want an ADIZ over the entire South China Sea, then like @Anneinak said it’s based on construction of a radar system on Scarborough Shoal.  The introduction of an ADIZ over the South China Sea would be solely for military purposes, as no country has threatened to go to war with China recently. This leads me to think that China does not need an ADIZ, as its just an official way of stating what they are already doing to the various foreign militaries. An article on The Diplomat published on the 12th March stated “The Chinese People’s Liberation Army- Navy will continue to shadow foreign military vessels and intercept aircraft in the SCS, according to comments last week by a senior PLAN official” (http://thediplomat.com/2017/03/chinas-navy-will-intercept-and-follow-military-vessels-and-aircraft/)  In May 2015 “China gave at least 6 warnings to the Philippine air force and navy planes to leave areas around the disputed South China Sea”. A commander of the Philippine Western Command said “As we were conducting routine maritime air patrols and flying in international airspace, our airforce aircraft was challenged over the radio” (http://uk.businessinsider.com/china-orders-philippine-military-to-leave-disputed-areas-of-south-china-sea-2015-5?r=US&IR=T)  In September 2015, a US spy plane was flying over Fiery Cross reef, where China was constructing an early warning radar station on reclaimed land. The US plane was ordered 8 times to leave the airspace despite the pilots pointing out they were in international airspace. (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/may/21/china-warns-us-plane-to-leave-airspace-over-disputed-islands) 
There have also been several incidences of China following US and Vietnamese navy ships.  It would be a very fast procedure for China to introduce an ADIZ by August 2017, they would want to make sure they could enforce it before rolling it out to avoid the problems of the East China Sea ADIZ.
